title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.8.27 | 22-02-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: My obeisances are unto you who are the property of the materially impoverished.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with prayers and then introduces Queen Kunti's prayer focusing on the Lord being the property of the materially impoverished.

segments.key_quote: The Supreme Lord is the property of the materially impoverished.
segments.summary: This segment discusses the concept of the Lord belonging to the materially impoverished and clarifies that it doesn't mean a living being can be a complete renouncer in the absolute sense.

segments.key_quote: A living being renounces something for gaining something more valuable.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that renunciation involves giving up something for a greater spiritual gain, not simply becoming empty-handed.

segments.key_quote: They give up material wealth to gain some spiritual wealth.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the example of the Goswamis of Vrindavan to illustrate how devotees renounce material possessions to gain spiritual wealth and devotion to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: The devotees are generally without material prosperity, but they have a very secret treasure house in the lotus feet of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates a story about Sanatana Goswami and a touchstone to illustrate that devotees possess a secret treasure in their devotion to the Lord, which is more valuable than material wealth.

segments.key_quote: Krishna Nama is the spiritual touchstone. It is not a material touchstone. It is a spiritual touchstone.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the holy name of the Lord is the true spiritual touchstone and that a factual devotee doesn't give material things but the supreme asset, Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Material hankerings and spiritual advancement go ill together.
segments.summary: This segment emphasizes that material desires and spiritual progress are incompatible, and neophyte devotees should distinguish between spirit and matter, lacking the spiritual vision to see them as one.

segments.key_quote: Material advancement is Anartha. It is not required.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by stating that material advancement is an unwanted thing (Anartha) that leads to entanglement and misery, and encourages listeners to give it up and embrace Krishna consciousness under the guidance of pure devotees.
